verses.text: And Hannah prayed and said, "My heart rejoices in the LORD; my horn is lifted high in the LORD. My mouth boasts over my enemies, for I rejoice in your salvation."
verses.comment: ‘Horn’ is a metaphor for strength, retained from the Hebrew.

verses.text: "There is none holy like the LORD; there is none besides you; there is no rock like our God."
verses.comment: ‘Rock’ as a title for God expresses His strength and reliability.

verses.text: "Do not keep speaking so arrogantly; let no arrogance come from your mouth; for the LORD is a God of knowledge, and by him actions are weighed."
verses.comment: Translation retains parallelism of Hebrew poetry.

verses.text: "The bows of the mighty are broken, but those who stumbled are girded with strength."
verses.comment: ‘Girded with strength’ means ‘made strong’, literal rendering.

verses.text: "Those who were full have hired themselves out for bread, but those who were hungry have ceased to hunger. The barren has borne seven, but she who has many children is forlorn."
verses.comment: ‘Barren’ and ‘seven’: seven is symbolic of completeness.

verses.text: "The LORD kills and brings to life; he brings down to Sheol and raises up."
verses.comment: ‘Sheol’ retained as the Hebrew word for the grave or underworld.

verses.text: "The LORD makes poor and makes rich; he brings low and he exalts."
verses.comment: Literal rendering of the Hebrew.

verses.text: "He raises the poor from the dust, he lifts the needy from the ash heap to make them sit with princes and inherit a seat of honor. For the pillars of the earth are the LORD’s, and he has set the world on them."
verses.comment: ‘Pillars of the earth’ is poetic imagery.

verses.text: "He guards the feet of his faithful ones, but the wicked are silenced in darkness; for not by strength shall man prevail."
verses.comment: ‘Silenced in darkness’ means destroyed or killed; literal rendering.

verses.text: "The adversaries of the LORD will be shattered; against them he will thunder in the heavens. The LORD will judge the ends of the earth; he will give strength to his king, and exalt the horn of his anointed."
verses.comment: ‘Anointed’ translates ‘Messiah’ and is prophetic.

verses.text: Then Elkanah went to Ramah at his house. And the boy ministered to the LORD before Eli the priest.
verses.comment: Retains ‘the boy’ as literal, referring to Samuel.

verses.text: Now the sons of Eli were worthless men; they did not know the LORD.
verses.comment: ‘Worthless men’ is literal; Hebrew: ‘sons of Belial’.

verses.text: This was the custom of the priests with the people: when any man offered a sacrifice, while the meat was being boiled, the priest’s servant would come with a three-pronged fork in his hand.
verses.comment: Rendering follows Hebrew sequence of actions.

verses.text: And he would thrust it into the pan, or kettle, or cauldron, or pot; all that the fork brought up the priest would take for himself. This is how they did at Shiloh to all the Israelites who came there.
verses.comment: All four types of vessels follow the Hebrew terms.

verses.text: Moreover, before the fat was burned, the priest’s servant would come and say to the man who was sacrificing, ‘Give meat to roast for the priest, for he will not accept boiled meat from you, but only raw.’
verses.comment: Retains emphasis on the ceremonial abuse.

verses.text: And if the man said to him, ‘Let them burn the fat first, and then take as much as you want,’ he would say, ‘No, you must give it now; if not, I will take it by force.’
verses.comment: Dialogue kept as close as possible to Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: So the sin of the young men was very great before the LORD, for they treated the LORD’s offering with contempt.
verses.comment: ‘Contempt’ renders the Hebrew root ‘bāzah’.

verses.text: Now Samuel was ministering before the LORD, a boy wearing a linen ephod.
verses.comment: ‘Linen ephod’ is a priestly garment, transliterated.

verses.text: His mother used to make him a little robe and brought it to him every year when she came up with her husband to offer the annual sacrifice.
verses.comment: ‘Little robe’ is a literal and affectionate term.

verses.text: And Eli would bless Elkanah and his wife, and say, ‘May the LORD give you children by this woman for the petition she asked of the LORD.’ And then they would return to their home.
verses.comment: Blessing formula maintained.

verses.text: Indeed the LORD visited Hannah, and she conceived and bore three sons and two daughters. And the boy Samuel grew in the presence of the LORD.
verses.comment: ‘Visited’ is literal, meaning God’s gracious intervention.

verses.text: Now Eli was very old, and he kept hearing all that his sons were doing to all Israel, and how they lay with the women who served at the entrance to the tent of meeting.
verses.comment: ‘Lay with the women’ is literal; their sexual sin is not softened.

verses.text: And he said to them, ‘Why do you do such things? For I hear of your evil dealings from all the people.’
verses.comment: Rendering preserves direct address.

verses.text: ‘No, my sons; it is not a good report that I hear. You make the LORD’s people transgress.’
verses.comment: ‘Transgress’ means ‘to sin’.

verses.text: ‘If a man sins against another man, God will mediate for him; but if a man sins against the LORD, who can intercede for him?’ But they would not listen to the voice of their father, for it was the LORD’s will to put them to death.
verses.comment: ‘It was the LORD’s will’ is literal; a difficult text.

verses.text: Now the boy Samuel continued to grow in stature and in favor with the LORD and also with man.
verses.comment: Parallel to description of Jesus in Luke.

verses.text: And a man of God came to Eli and said to him, ‘Thus says the LORD: "Did I not plainly reveal myself to the house of your father when they were in Egypt subject to the house of Pharaoh?"'
verses.comment: ‘Man of God’ is a prophet, as in Hebrew.

verses.text: "I chose him out of all the tribes of Israel to be my priest, to go up to my altar, to burn incense, to wear an ephod before me. And I gave to the house of your father all my offerings by fire from the people of Israel."
verses.comment: Clear listing of priestly privileges.

verses.text: "Why then do you kick at my sacrifice and my offering that I commanded, and honor your sons above me by fattening yourselves on the choicest parts of every offering of my people Israel?"
verses.comment: ‘Kick at my sacrifice’ shows contempt, literal idiom preserved.

verses.text: "Therefore the LORD, the God of Israel, declares: ‘I promised that your house and the house of your father should walk before me forever.’ But now the LORD declares: ‘Far be it from me! For those who honor me I will honor, and those who despise me will be lightly esteemed.'"
verses.comment: Quotation marks show direct speech from the LORD.

verses.text: "Behold, the days are coming when I will cut off your strength and the strength of your father’s house, so that there will not be an old man in your house."
verses.comment: ‘Strength’ is literally ‘arm’ in Hebrew, idiom for power.

verses.text: "Then you will look with envy at all the prosperity that will be bestowed on Israel, and there shall not be an old man in your house forever."
verses.comment: ‘Prosperity’ is from a Hebrew noun meaning ‘good’ or ‘favor’.

verses.text: "The only one of you whom I do not cut off from my altar shall be spared to weep his eyes out and grieve his heart, and all the descendants of your house shall die by the sword of men."
verses.comment: Literal rendering of consequences for Eli’s house.

verses.text: "And this will be the sign to you that shall come upon your two sons, Hophni and Phinehas: both of them shall die on the same day."
verses.comment: ‘Sign’ is literal, as in Hebrew; prophecy is plain.

verses.text: "And I will raise up for myself a faithful priest, who shall do according to what is in my heart and in my mind. And I will build him a sure house, and he will walk before my anointed forever."
verses.comment: Prophecy points to Zadok and ultimately Messiah.

verses.text: "And everyone who is left in your house will come and bow down to him for a piece of silver and a loaf of bread, saying, ‘Please appoint me to one of the priest’s offices that I may eat a morsel of bread.’"
verses.comment: Closes with vivid image of humiliation and poverty for Eli’s descendants.
